  • The treatment regimen for paucibacillary leprosy involves a 6-month course of drug therapy with 2 drugs (Dapsone, Rifampicin).
  • Diagnosis of leprosy under NLEP: It is currently based on clinical grounds (revised case definition) - 

 

Paucibacillary (PB) case: A case of leprosy with 1 to 5 skin lesions, without demonstrated presence of bacilli in a skin smear;

 

Multibacillary (MB) case: A case of leprosy with more than five skin lesions; or with nerve involvement (pure neuritis, or any number of skin lesions and neuritis); or with the demonstrated presence of bacilli in a slit-skin smear, irrespective of the number of skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

MDT blister pack Colour

 

PBL adult - Green color

 

MBL adult - Red color

 

PBL child - Blue color

 

MBL child - Yellow colour

choices.text: A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2
A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4
A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1
A-3, B-1, C-2, D-1

questions.text: Match the blood product with the shelf life mentioned in the next column: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

The shelf lives of various blood products are crucial for ensuring their efficacy and safety in clinical use. Here is the matching of blood products with their respective shelf lives:

 

Single donor platelet (A): These typically have a shelf life of 5 days (3.).

 

Packed red blood cells (B): These can be stored for up to 42 days depending on the preservative used (1.).

 

Cryoprecipitate (C): This blood product has a shelf life of 1 year when stored properly (4.).

 

Granulocyte concentrate (D): This product has a short shelf life of 24 hours (2.).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The shelf life of different blood products is essential for proper storage and timely usage in medical practice.

 

  • Single donor platelet - 5 days
  • Packed red blood cells - 42 days
  • Cryoprecipitate - 1 year
  • Granulocyte concentrate - 24 hours

choices.text: Primary active transport
Secondary active transport
Any of the above

questions.text: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary active transport

 

  1. Glucose enters the lumen of the small intestine.
  2. Sodium ions (Na+) are present in the lumen of the intestine.
  3. Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1) on the luminal membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose absorption:
    1. SGLT1 binds to both glucose and sodium ions.
    2. Sodium ions move down their electrochemical gradient into the enterocyte, providing energy for transport.
    3. Glucose molecules are co-transported with sodium ions into the enterocyte.
  4. Glucose enters the cytoplasm of the enterocyte.
  5. Inside the enterocyte, glucose can be used for energy or transported across the basolateral membrane.
  6. Glucose Transporter 2 (GLUT2) on the basolateral membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose transport out of the cell:
    1. GLUT2 allows glucose to move down its concentration gradient.
    2. Glucose diffuses across the basolateral membrane into the bloodstream.
  7. Glucose is carried away by the bloodstream to various tissues and organs for utilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Involves direct use of ATP for the movement of substances against their concentration gradient and does not apply to glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Option C. Facilitated diffusion: Passive movement of molecules along their concentration gradient through a membrane protein, applies to the exit of glucose at the basolateral side but not to its uptake at the luminal side.

 

Option D. Any of the above: Not applicable as the specific mechanism for glucose absorption is secondary active transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose is absorbed in the intestine through secondary active transport utilizing the Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1), which couples the energetically favorable transport of sodium with the transport of glucose against its gradient into enterocytes.

questions.text:
Which is the correct sequence for the correction of hypospadias? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Urethroplasty
  2. Meatoplasty
  3. Orthoplasty
  4. Glanuloplasty
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 → 1 → 4 → 2

 

The correct sequence for the correction of hypospadias is Option C. 3 → 1 → 4 → 2.

 

The main principles of surgery in hypospadias, in sequence, include:

 

  1. Orthoplasty: Corrects chordee (the abnormal curvature of the penis), which is the first step in the procedure to ensure proper straightening of the penis.
  2. Urethroplasty: Repositioning and tubularization of the urethra to ensure the proper opening at the distal end of the penis.
  3. Glanuloplasty: Reconstruction of the glans, forming the tip of the penis and covering the urethral opening.
  4. Meatoplasty: Reconstruction of the distal urethral meatus, which is the final step to ensure a functional and anatomically correct urethral opening.

 

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by a ventrally placed urethral meatus, a hooded foreskin, and ventral chordee (bending of the penis). The correction aims to restore both functional and cosmetic normality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This sequence places urethroplasty first, which is incorrect because chordee (orthoplasty) needs to be corrected first to ensure proper straightening before other steps.

 

Option B. This is a common but incorrect option, as it places urethroplasty before glanuloplasty, while glans reconstruction should be done before distal urethral meatoplasty.

 

Option D. The sequence is incorrect, placing urethroplasty and orthoplasty in the wrong order.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for hypospadias repair is orthoplasty first (to correct chordee), followed by urethroplasty, glanuloplasty, and finally meatoplasty to reconstruct the urethral opening.

questions.text: A researcher in epidemiology is planning to conduct a meta-analysis to better understand the effects of a specific intervention. While he lists the various stages and processes associated with a meta-analysis, he includes one element that isn't typically involved in a meta-analysis. Which of the following isn't directly associated with the process of a meta-analysis? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Randomization 

 

  • Randomization is not a part of the meta-analysis process but is a critical component of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), which may be included in a meta-analysis.
  • Meta-analysis involves analysis of multiple studies together.
  • Steps of Meta-analysis involves Hypothesis formation, Study selection, Formulation of data, Analysis of data, examining bias, formulating conclusion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selection: Involves selecting studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Option B. Analysis: Involves statistical analysis of the combined data from the selected studies.

 

Option D. Abstraction: Involves extracting data from the studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Randomization is a part of conducting individual randomized controlled trials, not the process of performing a meta-analysis.

choices.text: Parvovirus
Toxoplasma
HIV

questions.text: Which of these is the cause of Hydrops fetalis?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parvovirus

 

  • Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of hydrops fetalis. (Non immune hydrops)
  • Parvovirus B19 infects fetal erythroid progenitor cells and causes anemia.
  • Severe anemia leads to high-output cardiac failure and hydrops fetalis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. CMV: Typically causes peri-ventricular calcifications in the fetus.

 

Option C. Toxoplasmosis: Causes:  hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, cerebral calcification, microcephaly, seizures and mental retardation in the newborn.

 

Option D. HIV: Vertical transmission of HIV from mother to infant can occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of hydrops fetalis due to its effect on fetal erythroid progenitor cells, leading to severe anemia and subsequent high-output cardiac failure.

 

Ref: Page no 347, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text:
Match the following ocular drugs with respect to their side effects: 

 

Column A:

1. Amiodarone 

2. Digoxin

3. Systemic steroids 

4. Hydroxychloroquine

 

Column B:

A. Cataract

B. Retinopathy

C. Yellow vision

D. Corneal microdeposits
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b

 

The correct matches of the drugs with their side effects are:

 

  1. Amiodarone: d. Corneal microdeposits
    Amiodarone leads to the formation of whorl-like corneal microdeposits, also known as cornea verticillata or vortex keratopathy. These appear as gray or brown opacities in a whorled pattern on the corneal surface. The mechanism is related to the drug’s accumulation within the corneal epithelium due to its lipid affinity. Typically, these deposits are asymptomatic, but in some cases, patients may experience visual disturbances. Other medications, such as chloroquine, phenothiazines, and indomethacin, can also cause similar deposits.
  2. Digoxin: c. Yellow vision (Xanthopsia)
    Digoxin is known to cause xanthopsia, where the vision takes on a yellowish hue. This side effect is due to the drug’s action on the retina and visual pathways, altering color perception. Yellow vision is a common sign of digoxin toxicity, and other associated symptoms can include blurred vision and visual disturbances.
  3. Systemic steroids: a. Cataract
    Prolonged use of systemic steroids can lead to the development of cataracts, particularly posterior subcapsular cataracts. These cataracts form at the back of the lens and are more likely to impair vision compared to other types. The mechanism involves changes in lens protein structure and oxidative damage. In contrast, topical steroids are more often associated with increased intraocular pressure and glaucoma.
  4. Hydroxychloroquine: b. Retinopathy
    Hydroxychloroquine can result in toxic retinopathy, which damages the retinal layers, especially the macula. In the initial stages, retinal damage may not be visible on examination. As the condition progresses, a characteristic bull’s eye maculopathy can be seen, which features central pigmentation surrounded by a ring of depigmentation. This is due to the drug’s accumulation in the retina, where it binds to melanin and disrupts the function of photoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The key drug-specific ocular side effects: Amiodarone causes corneal microdeposits, Digoxin leads to yellow vision, systemic steroids can cause cataracts, and Hydroxychloroquine is linked with toxic retinopathy.

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4, E-5

 

The correct matching of the items is as follows:

 

  • Eonism (Transvestism): Wearing clothes of the opposite sex, often for sexual gratification or due to gender identity disorder.
  • Frotteurism: The act of rubbing one's genitals against another person, usually in a crowded place.
  • Necrophilia: Engaging in sexual activity with dead bodies.
  • Exhibitionism: The act of exposing one's genitalia to unsuspecting individuals.
  • Passive Algoglenia: Deriving sexual gratification from experiencing pain, also known as masochism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism (Transvestism) is wearing clothes of the opposite sex, Frotteurism is rubbing genitals against another person, Necrophilia is having sex with dead bodies, Exhibitionism is exposing genitalia to unsuspecting individuals, and Passive Algoglenia is gratification from experiencing pain.

questions.text: A young female has history of a induced abortion at 11 weeks. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mlU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine synechiae

 

Explanation:

 

Secondary amenorrhea following a spontaneous abortion and subsequent dilation and curettage (D&C) is typically due to intrauterine adhesions, also known as Asherman syndrome.

 

  • Uterine Synechiae (Asherman Syndrome): This condition involves the formation of scar tissue within the uterine cavity, leading to amenorrhea or menstrual abnormalities. It commonly occurs after uterine surgeries like D&C.
    • Diagnosis: Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing Asherman syndrome.
    • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the treatment to remove the adhesions and restore normal uterine cavity function.

Other options:

 

Option A. Pituitary dysfunction: This would typically be associated with abnormal levels of pituitary hormones, including FSH. The normal FSH level (6 mIU/ml) suggests that pituitary function is intact.

 

Option B. Ovarian dysfunction: This condition would generally present with elevated or depressed levels of FSH and other ovarian hormones. The normal FSH level suggests that ovarian function is likely normal.

 

Option C. First pregnancy: In pregnancy, FSH levels are very low (<0.1 mIU/ml). The FSH level of 6 mIU/ml makes this an unlikely cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary amenorrhea following a history of spontaneous abortion and D&C is usually due to intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome), diagnosed by hysteroscopy and treated with hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

 

Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sclerotic body

 

The histopathological picture shows brown coloured thick walled round cells that have transverse septations within them. These are called as Sclerotic bodies, also known as muriform cells or Medlar bodies, or copper penny appearance a found in tissue biopsies of patients with chromoblastomycosis. These bodies are a key diagnostic feature of this fungal infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Budding yeast: This is a general term for yeast cells reproducing through budding. It is not pathognomonic for a specific disease without further context.

 

Option C. Negri bodies are intracytoplasmic, round purplish structures with basophilic inner granules. They are pathognomic of rabies.

 

 

Option D. Asteroid bodies are oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. They are antigen-antibody complexes deposits. Seen in sporotricosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Few Important Pathognomonic structures associated with disease:

questions.text: A 16-year-old unmarried female has come to the gynae OPD for cervical cancer vaccination. Which is preferred? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gardasil

 

Explanation:

 

Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for cervical cancer prevention. It is a quadrivalent HPV vaccine that provides protection against four serotypes of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV): 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

  • HPV Serotypes Covered by Gardasil:
    • 6 and 11: These types are associated with anogenital warts.
    • 16 and 18: These types are linked to cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers.

 

Gardasil is administered as an intramuscular injection with a recommended schedule of three doses (0, 2, and 6 months).

 

Available HPV Vaccines:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 16 and 18.
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  3. Gardasil 9 (Nonavalent or HPV9): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent, covers serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biovac: This is a vaccine for Hepatitis A, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Option C. Rabivac: This is a rabies vaccine for animals, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Tvac: This is a tetanus vaccine, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for preventing cervical cancer and related HPV diseases, covering serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/teams/immunization-vaccines-and-biologicals/diseases/human-papillomavirus-vaccines-(HPV)

questions.text: Which type of sensation is carried by the 2nd order neuron of the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pain

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain. The second-order neurons in this nucleus relay these sensations to higher brain centers for processing. This pathway is crucial for the perception of painful stimuli and temperature changes, ensuring appropriate responses to potential dangers or injuries.

 

Note -

 

  • The trigeminal nerve has two types of nuclei: a motor nucleus and sensory nuclei.
  • The motor nucleus is singular and located in the pons.
  • The sensory nuclei are more numerous, consisting of three different nuclei distributed within the brainstem:
    • Mesencephalic Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (MNT): This nucleus is situated in the midbrain and is part of the sensory nuclei.
    • Chief Sensory Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (CNT): Located in the pons, this nucleus primarily handles the main sensory functions of the trigeminal nerve.
    • Spinal Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (also referred to as SNT): This extends down to the medulla and is involved with transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain.
  • Four nuclei: (3 sensory +1 Motor).
  • General somatic afferent:
    1. Mesencephalic (midbrain & pons): receives proprioceptive fibers from face
    2. Principal (main) sensory (pons): receives touch fibers from face.
    3. Spinal (pons, medulla & upper 2-3 cervical segments of spinal cord): receives pain & temperature sensations from face.
  • Special visceral efferent:

4. Motor nucleus (pons): supplies:

  • Four muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, medial & lateral pterygoid).
  • Other four muscles (Anterior belly of diagstic, mylohyoid, tensor tympani & tensor palati).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proprioception: Proprioception is managed by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus. This nucleus is responsible for sensing the position and movement of the jaw muscles, contributing to reflexes such as the jaw jerk.

 

Option B. Touch: The chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve handles the sensation of touch. This nucleus receives tactile information from the face and transmits it to the brain.

 

Option D. Vibration: Vibration sense is also managed by the chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. This nucleus is involved in processing detailed touch and vibratory sensations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve carries pain and temperature sensations, distinguishing it from the other nuclei responsible for proprioception, touch, and vibration.

questions.text: In the management of a thyroid storm, a critical and life-threatening condition due to an excess of thyroid hormone, a variety of medications are used to control the symptoms and the overactive thyroid. Which of the following drugs is not typically used in the treatment of thyroid storm? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspirin

 

Aspirin is avoided in thyroid storm because it can displace thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially increasing the levels of active thyroid hormone in the blood and exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options

 

Thyroid storm is a severe hypermetabolic state caused by an excessive release of thyroid hormones (thyrotoxicosis). The standard treatment includes:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used to manage the sympathetic symptoms of thyrotoxicosis like tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety. It also inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to the more active T3.

 

Option B. Lugol’s Iodine: Lugol's Iodine is given to decrease the synthesis and release of thyroid hormones. The high iodine content temporarily inhibits the synthesis of thyroid hormones (the Wolff-Chaikoff effect) and blocks their release into the circulation.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: Acetaminophen (paracetamol) is preferred for fever control in thyroid storm. It does not have the anti-inflammatory properties that might interfere with thyroid hormone levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin is not used in the treatment of thyroid storm because it can increase free thyroid hormone levels by displacing thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially worsening the condition.

questions.text: In 18th century British East India company used to transport which substance of abuse to China: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opium

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the British East India Company exported vast quantities of opium to China, leading to widespread addiction and the Opium Wars, which had significant geopolitical consequences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marijuana: A psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Option D. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China.

questions.text: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EGPA

 

Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA), formerly known as Churg-Strauss Syndrome, is characterized by a combination of asthma, eosinophilia, and vasculitis affecting multiple organ systems.

 

The clinical triad of skin lesions (such as purpura or nodules), asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex (manifesting as numbness, pain, or muscle weakness typically in the limbs), and eosinophilia is highly suggestive of this condition. EGPA is a type of ANCA-associated vasculitis but differs from others in its prominent eosinophilic involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis: Typically associated with hepatitis C infection and features immune complexes in the blood that precipitate in the cold. It commonly presents with palpable purpura, joint pains, and kidney involvement but not typically with eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): A medium vessel vasculitis that may present with similar features including neuropathy and skin lesions but does not typically include eosinophilia as a prominent feature.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis (GCA): Primarily affects large vessels, particularly the temporal arteries, and presents with symptoms such as headache, jaw claudication, and potential blindness. It does not feature the triad of skin lesions, mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EGPA is a distinctive form of vasculitis marked by asthma, eosinophilia, and a systemic vasculitis involving skin and nerves among other systems. Its recognition is crucial due to the need for early and aggressive treatment to prevent significant morbidity and mortality.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

questions.text:
True regarding mitochondrial DNA? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

  1. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome
  2. Single stranded Circular DNA
  3. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons
  4. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins
  5. Has around 16,000 base pairs
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, C, E

 

MITOCHONDRIAL DNA         

 

Statement A. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome: mtDNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA due to the lack of introns and protective histone proteins, which help prevent mutations in nuclear DNA.

 

Statement C. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons: mtDNA uses a slightly different genetic code. For example, the codon UGA, which is a stop codon in the universal genetic code, codes for tryptophan in mtDNA. Similarly, AGG and AGA code for arginine in the universal genetic code but are stop codons in mtDNA. AUA codes for isoleucine in the universal genetic code but codes for methionine in mtDNA.

 

 

Statement E. Has around 16,000 base pairs: mtDNA contains approximately 16,000 base pairs and 37 genes, which make up about 1% of the total cellular DNA.

                                   

Other Statements:

 

Statement B. Single stranded Circular DNA: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA is circular but double-stranded.

 

Statement D. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA encodes for only 13 of the 67 proteins required for the electron transport chain (ETC), which is approximately 19% of the total.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA, has a slightly different genetic code, and contains around 16,000 base pairs, encoding for a portion but not all of the proteins required for the electron transport chain.

questions.text: FRAX is related to: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture risk assessment 

 

  • FRAX or Fracture Risk Assessment Tool, is a screening tool that provides country-specific algorithms for estimating individualized 10-year probability of hip and major osteoporotic fracture and to target anti-osteoporosis treatments. 
  • It was created in 2008 at the University of Sheffield in the United Kingdom by the WHO Collaborating Centre for Metabolic Bone Diseases.
  • Many risk factors for fractures were identified and added to the tool through a series of comprehensive meta-analyses from 12 prospective population-based studies from North America, Europe, Asia, and Australia. 
  • FRAX uses 7 easily accessible clinical risk factors, which are entered into the calculation as yes or no. 
  • These factors include smoking, systemic glucocorticoid usage, excessive alcohol consumption, rheumatoid arthritis, parental hip fractures, past fragility fractures, and other causes of secondary osteoporosis. 
  • FRAX also takes into account body mass index (BMI), sex, and age. 
  • FRAX may calculate the fracture probability with or without femoral neck BMD, accommodating different situations.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fracture rehabilitation assessment: Rehabilitation focuses on restoring function and movement after a fracture has occurred. FRAX is used before a fracture, to predict the likelihood of one happening in the future.

 

Option C. Fracture repair assessment: Repair refers to the medical procedures (like surgery) used to fix a broken bone. FRAX is about predicting the risk of a fracture, not how it will be treated.

 

Option D. Fracture reduction assessment: Reduction is the process of setting a broken bone back into its proper alignment. FRAX doesn't assess the need for reduction, but rather the overall risk of a fracture occurring in the first place.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FRAX is a tool for prevention by identifying those at risk of fractures.

questions.text:
What characteristics define necrosis among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Disrupted cell membrane
  2. Induces inflammation
  3. Swelling of the cell
  4. Can be seen physiologically
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Necrosis is a form of cell injury that results in the premature death of cells in living tissue by autolysis. The following are the key characteristics of necrosis:

 

1. Disrupted cell membrane: Necrosis is characterized by the loss of cell membrane integrity, leading to the uncontrolled release of cellular contents into the extracellular space.

 

2. Induces inflammation: The release of cellular contents into the surrounding tissue causes an inflammatory response. This is a hallmark of necrosis, as the body reacts to the injury.

 

3. Swelling of the cell: In necrosis, cells typically swell and eventually rupture due to the loss of membrane integrity and the influx of water and ions.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Necrosis is never physiological: it always occurs as a result of pathological conditions. Unlike apoptosis, which is a programmed and regulated form of cell death, necrosis is unregulated and is usually detrimental to the organism.

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

FEATURES OF NECROSIS

questions.text: This powder is used in treatment of which poisoning? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphorus

 

The blue-colored powder referred to is copper sulfate (blue vitriol), which was historically used to treat phosphorus poisoning. Copper sulfate reacts with phosphorus to form cupric phosphide, which is non-toxic. While copper sulfate is no longer commonly used as an antidote due to its own toxicity, it remains a historically important treatment. The antidotes for phosphorus poisoning include KMnO4 (potassium permanganate) and CuSO4 (copper sulfate).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Arsenic: Incorrect. Arsenic poisoning is treated with chelating agents like DMPS (Dimercapto propanesulfonic acid), Dimercaprol (BAL), or Succimer (DMSA). Copper sulfate is not used in arsenic poisoning treatment.

 

Option C. Mercury: Incorrect. Mercury poisoning is treated with chelating agents like Dimercaprol, DMPS, or Succimer. Copper sulfate has no role in mercury poisoning treatment.

 

Option D. Lead: Incorrect. Lead poisoning is primarily treated with Dimercaprol + CaNa2EDTA, DMPS, or Succimer. Copper sulfate is not used in lead poisoning treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copper Sulphate (blue vitriol) was historically used to treat phosphorus poisoning but is no longer recommended due to its own toxicity. The current antidotes for phosphorus poisoning include KMnO₄ (Potassium Permanganate) and Copper Sulphate, although clinical use has largely been discontinued​.

questions.text: A 33-year-old public health officer is assigned to lead a healthcare team aiming to address and manage endemic conditions in a remote village with limited healthcare access. As part of the initiative, there's a proposal to start a mass drug administration (MDA) program targeting common health concerns in the area. Which of the following conditions would NOT traditionally be managed through mass drug administration? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Vitamin A deficiency 

 

  • Mass Drug Administration (MDA) refers to providing a drug to an entire population without considering age and gender.
  • Vitamin A prophylaxis is exclusively administered as per the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) to children up to the age of 5.
  • This prophylactic treatment is not intended as a curative measure but rather as a preventive measure.
  • Treatment with vitamin A is reserved solely for children displaying symptoms of vitamin A deficiency, and such treatment is not widespread throughout the community.
  • As a result, it is not categorized as part of Mass Drug Administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Worm infestation: Managed through MDA using albendazole or mebendazole to treat and prevent worm infestations in the population.

 

Option C. Scabies: Managed through MDA using ivermectin to treat and prevent scabies outbreaks in the community.

 

Option D. Filariasis: Managed through MDA using DEC (diethylcarbamazine) and albendazole to prevent and control filariasis in endemic areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin A deficiency is managed through targeted prophylaxis in children rather than mass drug administration.
  • In contrast, MDA is carried out for conditions like scabies (using ivermectin), worm infestations (using albendazole), and filariasis (using DEC + albendazole).

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spontaneous respiratory effort

 

  • The capnograph shows a characteristic pattern known as the curare notch or curare cleft.
  • This pattern indicates spontaneous inspiratory effort by the patient during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • This occurs when the patient attempts to breathe against the ventilator cycle, causing a dip in the capnograph waveform.
  • The appropriate next step would be to paralyze the patient again by administering an additional dose of muscle relaxant to ensure proper synchronization with the ventilator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal intubation: In cases of esophageal intubation, the capnograph typically shows a very low or absent end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) reading because the endotracheal tube is not in the trachea, leading to little to no CO2 being detected. The waveform would be almost flat.

 

 

Option B. Inspiration with cardiac oscillations: Cardiac oscillations can appear on the capnograph as small oscillations or ripples on the expiratory plateau due to the beating of the heart causing minor fluctuations in airway pressure. This is not characterized by a distinct cleft or notch.

 

 

Option C. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm causes a "shark fin" appearance on the capnograph due to obstructed airflow and prolonged expiration. The waveform would show a slanted, rather than a squared-off, expiratory plateau.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A curare notch or cleft on a capnograph indicates spontaneous respiratory effort in a patient who is supposed to be fully ventilated under muscle relaxants, requiring re-administration of the muscle relaxant to ensure proper mechanical ventilation.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1311

questions.text: Which of the following organisms cause multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus multilocularis

 

E. multilocularis leads to alveolar or multilocular hydatid cyst. The liver is the most commonly affected organ. The multilocular infiltrating lesion appears like a grossly invasive growth, without any fluid or free brood capsule or scolices which can be mistaken for a malignant tumor.

 

Patients present with upper quadrant and epigastric pain. Liver enlargement and obstructive jaundice may also be present. It may also metastasize to the spleen, lungs and brain in 2% cases.

 

The prognosis is very grave and if untreated, 70% cases progress to death.

 

Surgical resection, when possible, is the best method of treatment. Albendazole therapy is recommended for 2 years after curative surgery. In those cases, where surgery is not possible, indefinite treatment with albendazole is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Echinococcus granulosus: Causes cystic echinococcosis or hydatid disease, which typically involves the formation of fluid-filled cysts rather than alveolar-like lesions.

 

Option C. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes amoebic liver abscesses, which are different in appearance and pathology from the lesions caused by Echinococcus multilocularis.

 

Option D. Cysticercus cellulose: The larval stage of Taenia solium, which causes cysticercosis. It can form cysts in various tissues but does not cause alveolar-like lesions in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver, leading to a serious condition known as alveolar echinococcosis. The prognosis is poor without treatment, emphasizing the importance of early detection and appropriate therapy.

questions.text: Which contrast agent is safe in a patient with renal failure? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG contrast agents

 

Ultrasound (USG) contrast agents, specifically SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are safe to use in patients with renal failure. These microbubbles are filled with gas and are excreted via the lungs rather than the kidneys, making them suitable for patients with compromised renal function. Unlike other contrast agents, USG contrast agents do not rely on renal clearance, thereby avoiding the risk of further renal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI contrast agents (Gadolinium-based): These agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, a serious condition affecting the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Iodinated contrast: Commonly used in CT imaging, these agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, which can further impair renal function.

 

Option D. CT contrast agent: Typically, iodinated contrast is used in CT imaging, which is not safe for patients with renal failure for the reasons mentioned above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

USG contrast agents, such as SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are the only contrast agents safe for use in patients with renal failure as they are excreted via the lungs and do not rely on renal clearance.

questions.text: Toluidine blue staining is used in the Identification of which of the following cells? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mast Cell

 

Toluidine blue is the special stain for mast cells.

 

Toluidine blue (also known as tolonium chloride) is an acidophilic metachromatic dye that selectively stains acidic tissue components (sulfates, carboxylates, and phosphate radicals). Toluidine blue (TB. has an affinity for nucleic acids, and therefore binds to nuclear material of tissues with a high DNA and RNA content.

 

It also intensely stains some substances leading to a change in color. This effect known as metachromasia.

 

  • Orthochromatic Staining - structures stained blue (Lymphocytes)
  • Metachromatic Staining - structures stained dark purple from polymeric aggregates formed when binding to high concentrations of polyanions (Mast cells)

 

Toluidine blue is often used to identify mast cells by virtue of heparin (which is very polyanionic. found in their secretion granules.

 

 

Application of Toluidine Blue

 

  1. Connective tissue mucins, especially acid mucins. The tissue stains purple to red, while the background is stained blue.
  2. Mast cell granules stain purple in color due to the presence of heparin and histamine.
  3. Amyloid stain blue but under polarized light they give a bright red birefringence.
  4. Endocrine cell granules are stained purple to red.
  5. Sulfatides stain red brown or yellow. Only lipids that are sufficiently acidic to induce a metachromatic shift are stained.
  6. Corynebacterium diphtheria contains granules with polymerized inorganic polyphosphate, which stains red violet color.
  7. Helicobacter stains dark blue against a variably blue background.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphocyte: Lymphocytes can be stained with toluidine blue, but they show orthochromatic staining (blue), not the metachromasia that is characteristic of mast cells.

 

Option B. Fibroblast: Fibroblasts are not specifically identified by toluidine blue staining.

 

Option C. Macrophage: While macrophages can be stained with various dyes, they do not exhibit the metachromasia seen in mast cells with toluidine blue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toluidine blue is primarily used to identify mast cells due to their characteristic metachromatic staining caused by the heparin in their granules.

questions.text: Relapse is seen in? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasmodium viva and ovale

 

Malaria relapse:

 

  • In case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which multiply inside hepatic cells to form schizonts and others persist and remain dormant as hypnozoites.
  • True relapse is caused due to hypnozoites (resting forms). Some get activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.
  • In case of Plasmodium falciparum and malaria, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence relapse is not seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmodium vivax and falciparum: While P. vivax can cause relapse, P. falciparum does not form hypnozoites and therefore does not cause relapse.

 

Option B. Plasmodium ovale and falciparum: P. ovale can cause relapse due to hypnozoites, but P. falciparum does not form hypnozoites.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax and malariae: P. vivax causes relapse due to hypnozoites, but P. malariae does not form hypnozoites and does not cause relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relapse in malaria is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale due to the presence of hypnozoites, the dormant liver stages that can reactivate and cause renewed infection.

questions.text: The drug of choice for treating scrub typhus? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Doxycycline

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, is effectively treated with Doxycycline, which is considered the first-line treatment. Doxycycline is administered at a dosage of 100 mg twice daily for 7 to 14 days. It disrupts protein synthesis in the bacterium, which is crucial for its effectiveness against this intracellular pathogen.

 

In pregnancy/children- Azithromycin/ chloramphenicol preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: While it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, it is not the preferred treatment for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Chloramphenicol: This is an alternative treatment option but is generally reserved for cases where doxycycline or azithromycin cannot be used.

 

Option D. Azithromycin: This is a suitable alternative, especially in special populations such as pregnant women and children, where doxycycline is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doxycycline is the first-choice medication for treating scrub typhus in adults and non-pregnant women, offering effective relief and eradication of the pathogen when taken for the recommended duration.

questions.text: The histopathology picture below is suggestive of? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • The given slide shows a row of tombstones' appearance, which is classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated.

 

 

  • Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3.
  • Hemidesmosomes help in connecting basal layer to underlying dermo-epidermal junction, in pemphigus vulgaris there are no antibodies against Hemidesmosomes, so the basal layer remains attached to the underlying dermo-epidermal junction giving the classical Row of tombstones appearance.
  • The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen.
  • Oral mucosa is commonly affected.

 

 

  • Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.
  • Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back as seen in the image below.

 

 

Biopsy: The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones.

 

 

IMAGE of row of tombstones appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis vulgaris:

 

  • This is an autoimmune disease characterized by hyperproliferation of keratinocytes leading to thickened, scaly plaques.
  • Histologically, it shows parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum), elongation of rete ridges, and a neutrophilic infiltrate (Munro's microabscesses) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not a feature of psoriasis.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis:

 

  • It's a parasitic infection caused by the Leishmania species.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by macrophages containing the parasite (Leishman-Donovan bodies) in the dermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not seen in leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • This is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
  • Histologically, there is an atypical lymphocytic infiltrate in the epidermis (epidermotropism), and the formation of Pautrier's microabscesses (collections of lymphocytes in the epidermis) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It does not exhibit a tombstone appearance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histopathology image suggests Pemphigus vulgaris, which is characterized by intraepidermal blistering due to acantholysis, or separation of keratinocytes, as a result of autoantibody attack on desmosomal proteins.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1

Robbins & cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10e- page no 1160

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left hypoactive labyrinth

 

  • A left hypoactive labyrinth is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features.
  • Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component.
  • The fast component denotes the direction of the nystagmus.
  • Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, and trauma to the labyrinth cause nystagmus to the healthy side.
  • Serous labyrinthitis (irritative lesion) leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior canal BPPV: Characterized by positional vertigo and typically vertical nystagmus, related to the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Option B. Superior canal BPPV: Also known as anterior canal BPPV, would cause primarily vertically oriented nystagmus, not horizontal.

 

Option C. Right hypoactive labyrinth: Would produce nystagmus with the slow component towards the right and the fast component towards the left, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The direction of the slow and fast components of nystagmus is crucial in diagnosing the affected side in vestibular disorders. A left hypoactive labyrinth leads to nystagmus with a fast component to the right, matching the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 43

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve passing through the given structure: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IV

 

Explanation:

 

In the given image, the dorsal aspect of the brainstem is marked and the cranial nerve that is passing there is the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

 

Trochlear nerve

 

  • Origin : The trochlear nerve is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal (posterior) aspect of the brain. Specifically, it originates from the dorsal surface of the midbrain, below the inferior colliculus.
  • Exit proceed to the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbit.
  • Function: It is a motor nerve that innervates a single extraocular muscle, the superior oblique muscle. The primary action of the superior oblique muscle is to intort (rotate inward), depress, and abduct the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (III):

 

  • Origin: The oculomotor nerve originates in the anterior aspect of the midbrain. Specifically, its fibers arise from the oculomotor nucleus, which is located in the superior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Exit Point: After emerging from the midbrain, it exits the brainstem at the level of the interpeduncular fossa (the space between the cerebral peduncles).
  • Function: It innervates most of the muscles controlling eye movements. It also contains parasympathetic fibers that are involved in pupil constriction and the lens's accommodation.

 

Option B. Facial Nerve (VII):

 

  • Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons. Specifically, its fibers come from the facial nerve nucleus.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, between the pons and the medulla. It exits lateral to the abducens nerve and medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • Function: The facial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression. It also has taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and carries parasympathetic fibers to salivary and lacrimal glands.
     

Option D. Abducens Nerve (VI):

 

  • Origin: The abducens nerve originates in the pons. Its fibers arise from the abducens nucleus, which is located in the dorsal pons near the floor of the fourth ventricle.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the ventral surface of the brainstem at the junction between the pons and the medulla, in the groove between the pons and the pyramid of the medulla.
  • Function: It innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve is the fourth cranial nerve that originates in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus from the trochlear nuclei. It is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the brainstem's dorsal surface and has the longest intracranial course.

 

The main actions of superior oblique are:

 

  • Depression in adducted position- Patients with trochlear nerve palsy have difficulty in looking downwards when eyes are in the adducted position.
  • Abduction
  • Intorsion of the eyeball.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arachnoid mater

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure you will pierce while performing a lumbar puncture.

 

Layers pierced while performing lumbar puncture/spinal anesthesia (subarachnoid space) from outside to inside are:

 

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater

 

Upon piercing the arachnoid mater, you enter the subarachnoid space (lumbar cistern), where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected during a lumbar puncture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligamentum flavum: The ligamentum flavum is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is pierced before the dura mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option B. Dura mater: The dura mater is a tough outer meningeal layer that is pierced before the arachnoid mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option D. Pia mater: The pia mater is the innermost meningeal layer that directly covers the spinal cord. It is not pierced during a lumbar puncture.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure pierced before entering the lumbar cistern during a lumbar puncture.

choices.text: Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidas

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine, except: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

 

  • Hyponatremia is more commonly observed in individuals taking oxcarbazepine compared to those taking carbamazepine.
  • Both of these antiepileptic drugs can contribute to hyponatremia by enhancing the effects of ADH (antidiuretic hormone), leading to increased retention of water, which in turn reduces the osmolarity and causes hyponatremia. However, the incidence of hyponatremia appears to be higher with oxcarbazepine when compared to carbamazepine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotension: Hypotension is more commonly seen with carbamazepine. It can affect cardiovascular function and lead to decreased blood pressure.

 

Option C. Rash: Rash is a common side effect of both drugs, but it is more frequently seen with carbamazepine. Skin reactions can range from mild to severe, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

 

Option D. Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidases (GGT): Elevated GGT levels are more commonly associated with carbamazepine use. GGT is an enzyme found in the liver, and its elevated levels can indicate liver enzyme induction or liver injury, which is more common with carbamazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. While both drugs can cause similar side effects due to their similar mechanisms of action, certain adverse effects, such as hypotension, rash, and elevated GGT levels, are more frequently seen with carbamazepine.

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CPR with 20% intralipid

 

  • The scenario described involves a young male patient who received a regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure and subsequently became unresponsive with an unrecordable pulse.
  •  These are concerning signs of Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST), which can occur when local anesthetic drugs like bupivacaine enter the systemic circulation.
  • The best course of management for this patient is as follows:
  • This is the correct choice. Intralipid is a lipid emulsion used as the antidote for LAST.
  • It works by sequestering the local anesthetic drug in the lipid phase and reducing its toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.
  •  CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) should be initiated, and 20% intralipid should be administered intravenously to treat LAST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CPR with sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is not the first-line treatment for LAST. While it can be used to treat certain cardiac arrhythmias caused by local anesthetic toxicity, it does not directly counteract the toxic effects on the central nervous system and is not as effective as intralipid.

 

Option C. CPR with dobutamine: Dobutamine is a medication used to increase cardiac output and blood pressure in some situations, but it is not the primary treatment for LAST.

 

Option D. CPR with calcium: Calcium does not reverse the toxic effects of local anesthetic systemic toxicity. Therefore, it is not the appropriate treatment for this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient experiences LAST with signs of cardiovascular collapse and central nervous system toxicity, the recommended treatment is CPR (if necessary) along with the administration of 20% intralipid intravenously, as it helps to reverse the toxic effects of the local anesthetic and improve the patient's condition.
  • Drug of choice for treatment of LAST – 20% Intralipid IV

choices.text: Nicotine gum

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective drug in smoking cessation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is the most effective drug in smoking cessation. Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 nicotinic receptors. It is one of the 1st line oral drugs that is used for smoking cessation. The other drugs are Bupropion, even Nicotine replacement in the form of gums, lozenge, patch, spray can also be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buspirone: Primarily used for the treatment of anxiety disorders, buspirone is not used for smoking cessation. Bupropion is used for smoking cessation.

 

Option C. Nicotine gum: As a form of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), nicotine gum helps to reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings by supplying a small amount of nicotine. While effective for many people, it may be less effective than prescription medications like varenicline, especially for heavy smokers.

 

Option D. Rimonabant: This drug was initially developed as an anti-obesity medication and was found to also have some effect on smoking cessation. However, it was withdrawn from the market due to psychiatric side effects, including depression and suicidal thoughts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Varenicline is the most effective medication for smoking cessation. It works as a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors, helping to alleviate withdrawal symptoms and reduce the rewarding effects of nicotine. This makes it a highly effective option for individuals seeking to quit smoking.

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique is '2'.

 

 

The sandwich ELISA is a type of Enzyme-linked immunosorbent Assay that uses two antibodies: a capture antibody and a detection antibody. It is called a sandwich because your antigen is bound between antibodies. The purpose of any ELISA is to detect the presence of a target antigen in a sample. In a sandwich ELISA the target antigen is bound between a capture antibody and a detection antibody. The capture antibody is immobilized on a surface, while the detection antibody (conjugated to an enzyme or fluorophore label) is applied as a last step before quantitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Represents the substrate that produces a detectable signal when reacted with the enzyme.

 

Option C. 3: Represents the primary detection antibody that binds to the antigen.

 

Option D. 4: Represents the capture antibody that is immobilized on the surface and captures the antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the sandwich ELISA technique, the enzyme conjugate is part of the detection antibody, which binds to the antigen and, upon addition of a substrate, produces a detectable signal. In this diagram, '2' is identified as the enzyme conjugate.
